title: Moineau stepper extruder Luer lock updates

description.text: in progress...

some mods on: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15538 First is a nozzle end that has space for a luer-lock adapter salvaged from a syringe. Instead of the original nozzle there is a hole of 9.5mm in which you can fit a salvaged luer-lock. Cut one from a syringe and remove the flange bits. Now use some glue to fix and water tight the luer-lock into the hole. Now in instead of dismantling your extruder in order to change nozzle (or unclog) you just screw in a new lure-lock tip. First tests: http://youtu.be/YWDGTfmd7IA

comments.text:
Hi unfold
I think it's amazing design.In the video, I saw you use pump to push the clay, Do you use solenoid valve to control the air pressure? Besides these, how can I use the opensource like reprap to do it? Do you use marlin and arduino? Could you please give me some information about it.
My email : [email protected] Thank you!
Best wish.
comments.author: sunny123321sky

comments.text: No, air pressure is constant. You don't want to control the air, is pushes with constant pressure just to feed the clay into the extruder. Control is done by the moineau pump. It's drop in compatible with Reprap, you just need to experiment with steps/mm settings etc. Yes, Marlin is fine. You control it like any other stepper based extruder.
comments.author: sunny123321sky

comments.text: Thanks for your reply!
comments.author: unfold

comments.text: yes, that's right. When motor turns, clay moves forward (or backward if it can overcome the air pressure). The air pressure is only there to help the clay move into the extruder. I don't see any reason why you would want to remove the pressure while not extruding? Air pressure works kind of on demand. Think of it like this: if the motor doesn't turn and clay isn't moving, no new air is pushed into your clay cartridge, just maintaining the pressure. If the motor turns, the pressure in the cartridge will drop and your air system will maintain the set pressure by pushing in extra air from the main vessel. If you depressurise your container in between you tend create problems if you have tiny air bubbles in your clay, also many syringes will rapidly disintegrate of you pressurise/depressurise them too often, you create little cracks that burst.
comments.author: sunny123321sky

comments.text: OK, thanks a lot.

title: Adjustable tension carriage (Max Micron and other Prusa i3)

description.text:
••this is still in development- any constructive feed back is welcome••
(I'm currently using version 2, version 3 has only minor additions but let me know of any issues please)

Got tired of the difficulties installing a properly tensioned belt on my Max Micron printer. It's either too tight or too loose. And then the add on type adjustable tensioners mostly are prone to breaking or "lean" the belt. then the springs and arch type clip on tensioners cause vibrations and/or bind the movement of the belt.

So I designed this. Sorta set it and forget it tensioner, but has the ability to be adjusted down to road to counter printer wear and such.

thoughts/benefits
• no vibration or feed back into prints
• no loss of travel length like clips or "ziptie" methods that can hit the pulley or motor on extreme travel.
• Stronger than most pulley adjuster setups I've seen and used.
• cleaner belt alignment & movement over "clip on" tensioners
• set it and forget it (but can still be adjusted later)
• all nuts are inset for ease and less tools needed
• belt tension tightens nut to maintain hold. the hard it pulls, the tighter it gets.
• all mounting and screws should stay the same as stock with just the addition of the M5 nut and bolt for the adjuster.

•• note #1- tolerances are kinda tight, recommend 0.1 or better resolution and 50% infill for strength••

•• note #2 - belt tightens with bolt tightening, use caution not to over tighten belt! ••

comments.text: Printing this tonight
comments.author: Al_Ross

comments.text: it works really well..  been using it since I designed it and haven't had an issue.. really makes the bed movement better!!  I highly recommend the bearing end that is marked "3mm lift".. as it should give you a near perfect straight belt path..

comments.text: what didn't work/fit?   make sure you have a really straight "belt path"   also make sure your printer is printing square and straight... I have a simple triangle that will check for square and straight printer setup...  leave on build plate anfter printing if possible and check with a square... also you can measure height-width-length.. they should all be exactly the same.  if one is off you have stepper's set incorrect for the movement...

Can light sand the barrel also .. or both to get a decent fit.  But remember, it should be rather tight though so it grips well...

This project demostrates the basic functionality of gyroscope. A gyroscope is a spinning wheel or disc in which the axis of rotation is free to assume any orientation by itself. When rotating, the orientation of the axis is unaffected by tilting or rotation of the mounting, according to the conservation of angular momentum. Because of this, gyroscopes are useful for measuring or maintaining orientation. The rotor of gyroscope made by Sphero.

This gyroscope consists of three circles as gimbal and holder. These circles can by printed in one piece. Each circle is a substraction of two spheres. Dimensions are calculated for Sphero as a gyroscope as rotor.

description.header: Project: Gyrosphero - gyroscope powered by sphero
description.text:
Overview & Background

By completing this project one can observe and practice the prinicple of gyroscope.

Within mechanical systems or devices, a conventional gyroscope is a mechanism comprising a rotor journaled to spin about one axis, the journals of the rotor being mounted in an inner gimbal or ring; the inner gimbal is journaled for oscillation in an outer gimbal for a total of two gimbals.

The outer gimbal or ring, which is the gyroscope frame, is mounted so as to pivot about an axis in its own plane determined by the support. This outer gimbal possesses one degree of rotational freedom and its axis possesses none. The next inner gimbal is mounted in the gyroscope frame (outer gimbal) so as to pivot about an axis in its own plane that is always perpendicular to the pivotal axis of the gyroscope frame (outer gimbal). This inner gimbal has two degrees of rotational freedom.

The axle of the spinning wheel defines the spin axis. The rotor is journaled to spin about an axis, which is always perpendicular to the axis of the inner gimbal. So the rotor possesses three degrees of rotational freedom and its axis possesses two. The wheel responds to a force applied about the input axis by a reaction force about the output axis.

The behaviour of a gyroscope can be most easily appreciated by consideration of the front wheel of a bicycle. If the wheel is leaned away from the vertical so that the top of the wheel moves to the left, the forward rim of the wheel also turns to the left. In other words, rotation on one axis of the turning wheel produces rotation of the third axis.

source Wiki https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gyroscope

A gyroscope in operation. Note the freedom of rotation in all three axes. The rotor will maintain its spin axis direction regardless of the orientation of the outer frame. Objectives
  • basic physical principles
  • principle of gyroscope
  • using of gyroscope
  • design of simple machine
Audiences

The principle of gyroscope is usually part of the curriculum of secondary schools (13-years old pupils). Complex use of gyroscope and designing your own gyroscope can bet he task for older students.

Subjects
  • Physics
  • Geometry
  • Engineering
Skills Learned

With designing your own gyroscope students will learn how to design simple machine, practical demonstration of gyroscope priniciple.

Lesson
  • Design software
  • 3D printer
  • Sphero ball

1) Design your own gyroscope or prepare this design for 3D printing.
2) Print all parts of gyroscope, each part can by in different color.
3) Install Sphero into the smallest ring.
4) Control Sphero as a rotor by App.

Duration
  • Designing - 5-10h
  • Printing - 5h
Preparation

This project does not need any special preparations.

Videos

https://youtu.be/ghqxlEDFjOo
https://youtu.be/xvQ4Oucdgas

I made these files to verify my 3D printer built accurate part geometry regardless of part orientation. There's a series of star-shaped shafts at various angles, and a series of disks with star-shaped openings that should fit over any of the shafts in all 8 rotations. A recent comment by Tony Buser (http://www.thingiverse.com/derivative:21136) got me thinking that this might be an instructive test for hobby printers, too.

On a hobby FDM printer (eg: Cupcake, BFB300, etc.) the untilted starshaft00.stl and stardisk00.stl will probably print and fit together just fine. The disk should fit onto the shaft in any of its 8 positions. But tilted versions of the shaft and disk, like starshaft30.stl and stardisk20.stl, will probably deviate from the star-shaped cross section sufficiently that the fit of the disk will vary...if it fits at all. If you want to customize the angle, spacing, or shape just edit starshaft.scad with OpenSCAD.

title: 2020 mountable Keyboard Tray for Rii Ultra Slim Wireless Keyboard (or similar). Long and Short versions

description.text:
This is a simple keyboard tray that mounts to a 2020 extrusion. It was designed specifically to hold this Rii K12 Ultra Slim Wireless Keyboard/touchpad: http://amzn.to/2ghaDOl

It can of course hold other keyboards or items.

I use this in conjunction with my 7 inch Raspberry Pi Touch screen and Pi 2 to run Octoprint. It provides a nice little kiosk on the printer itself.

The 7 in LCD mount can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1670214
The 7 in Touchscreen can be purchased here: http://amzn.to/2g6p5dr

UPDATED: Added a shorter version for those with a print surface of 200mm.

Printer:

FolgerTech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

I designed this to be able to print without supports. I suggest using a brim since there is a very long, thin segment that touches the bed. The brim helps avoid warping since there is so little material touching the build surface.

Use a layer height of 0.20 or 0.15 and an infill of at least 50% for strength.

If printing with PLA, use the cooling fan from layer 2 until end. If you using ABS, turn the fan on about 40% when the print reaches the very top of the print, where the inner edge begins to taper out.

Mounting

Mount the tray to a vertical 2020 extrusion with Three 5mm bolts w/T-nuts. 4mm can work, but I would recommend using washers to cover the excess gap.

So, i needed a spool holder, whipped one up in rhino. rev 1 didn't hold the velleman spools i got at Microcenter(First national chain i know of to sell filament, which is awesome!), so i remade it. This can accommodate a spool that is less than 8.5" in diameter and less than 3.75" wide the inside of the spool needs to be at least 1" in diameter, but you could modify that if you so desired. I used the feet on the spool to lock into the base plate tha i also had my printer 's feet locked in, just with a  pressure fit. I used the Lasercutter that is at the Baltimore Hackerspace to make one and finished it off with a 6" piece of pipe that was lying around.

I imported the dxf file into the redlaser software and cut an oak piece of plywood i got at lowes that was .20 thick.   
its a little tight, so don't be afraid to push on it to get it to snap together. i took a razor to the inside corner of the holes the tabs go in to make it seat a bit easier. I used wood glue and clamped the pieces together and after 30 min, it sets.   
I cut a scrap piece of 1" schedule 40 pipe 6" long and rounded the edge of the pipe i used to make insertion and removal easier. I cut it with a a port-a-band saw and rounded the edges with a grinding wheel.

title: Z-probe holder for Makerfarm i3 with auto bed-level

description.text: Here is a holder to mount your Z-endstop on a servo.  Works with a 9g servo, but is easily customizable to whatever you're using.  This is intended for use on a Makerfarm Prusa i3 with Alex Borro/ Matterhackers' auto bed-leveling mod.

Print this part.  Insert the "shoulder" of your servo into the hole at the end of the main arm.  Take the "single-arm" actuator/accessory, place it so that it extends along the "Slot side" of the arm.  Use some m2.5 screws to attach your switch to the slot on the end of the arm and secure with the small accessory screw.  
Use with either Alex Borro's replacement x-carriage end, or my parametric version.

description.text:
This is a minor remix of Robotnik's (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:127181) original spool holder design.

Modifications made:

A slotted side allowing the entire holder to be forced open slightly to hold two 608 bearings somewhat "locked in".
This slot also increases the flexibility of the holder if spool holder and actual filament spool doesn't meet up perfectly.

Some volume has been added in certain places of the holder since it now has to be a bit stronger than before.

Printer:

Duplicator i3 Ultra

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print using atleast 0.8mm shell thickness and 100% infill with a somewhat flexible PLA if you have it (for example PLA+ or other new enhanced PLA). Otherwise the stress of opening the holder up to push in the bearings might be to much for the plastic if unlucky.

However, this should be a non issue for PLA+, ABS and Nylon filaments.

description.text: I've been making a bunch of cool little vase things lately because I think they do a great job of showing off what 3D printers are capable of. I felt bad only using designs that other people made and then showing them off to my 3D design class, so I decided to make my own.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

I did 0% infill, no top shells, 3 side shells and 4 bottom shells. The specifics are up to you, but if you want it to be like a vase, then 0 Infill and no top shells are a must.

I used Inventor to make it. It was really just a bunch of rectangles that I swept with a twist and a taper. You can make some cool looking designs this way, so feel free to play around with this feature if you're interested in making your own.

I've been making decals for a little while now and ones I have made months ago are still sticking to my windows. You have to use the smooth side (the side that was touching the build plate) and make sure the surface you are sticking it to is clean. Wet with water and place on the window, mirror or shower wall. Overall the lower the shore hardness of the flexible filament you use NinjaFlex = 85A, Filaflex = 82A the better they stick. I've found the stiffer stickers SainSmart =95A, Semiflex = 98A, and Cheetah 95A are a little heavier and sometimes they fall off. That said I have a Semiflex butterfly still sticking.

print_settings.Notes:: Use high infill for strength. You don't want this part wobbly.

description.text:
This is an adatper/mountblock to mount an Anti-backlash nut onto an Ultimaker 2 printbed instead of the infamous chinese brass nuts

I have made a youtube video showing the difference between the standard brass nut and this adapter + backlash nut.

The adapter can be used where-ever brass nuts have been used, and where the space constraints permits.

The border is meant to help keep the Anti-Backlash Nut centered

Go here to see an Autodesk 3D model, which you can download in different file formats.
I used Autodesk Fusion 360 to create this model.
There is standard STL download here on Thingiverse as normal :)

Printer:

JennyPrinter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,25

Infill:

70

Notes:

I've used 3 perimeters using a 0,4mm nozzle.
You want to use a resolution/layerheight which you can divide up into 4 and 5mm without decimals.

Use high infill for strength. You don't want this part wobbly.

Insert m3 nuts into cut-outs

Just insert 2x m3 nuts into the bottom of the piece. Use glue if you can't make them stay where you want them to.

Attach the adapter to the printbed, or other surface.

Screw on the Anti-BackLash nut onto the adapter using 2x m3 nuts.

Important: You must get it centered. I recommend you do not lie the printer down on it's side, as the bearings on the 12mm rods will shift some.

Take it slow! Mount adapter and make sure it is centered, by mounting motor and leadscrew.. run the bed up and down some.. do the same after you attach the anti-backlash nut.

Just insert 2x m3 nuts into the bottom of the piece. Find 4x fitting screws with round head. Loosely mount the Anti-backlash nut and then tighten it down when you are sure it is centered.

Why I used m3 screws instead of m4?

To conserve space and make the item stronger, and because it's not normal having such short m4 screws lying around :)

You need to cut material away from the Anti-BackLash nut

If you use the bed-cover for Ultimaker 2, you need to cut away some of the base of the Anti-BackLash nut.

You can use this adapter as a guide for cutting.
I strongly recommend using a pillow-block to fix your lead-screw in the top before using this adapter!

title: Parametric 9g Servo mount for Makerfarm i3 with auto bed leveling

description.text: This is just a parametric version of Alex Borro's replacement end for the Makerfarm Prusa i3 x-carriage with auto bed leveling.

comments.text: For anyone who is interested, I have modified the Marlin firmware further to deal with the end stop bumping into the print bed when the servo retracts. It isn't the neatest, cleanest, fastest or most efficient way of doing it but it works like a charm! The Z Axis will move up a few mm then retract the Z end stop then it will drop back down the same amount and proceed to move to the next point for measuring, but it does add some time to the steps because of the extra motion. I personally would rather take the extra 5 seconds to do this than to have the servo horn chewed up due to the bumping.  Please let me know if it was helpful or if you have any improvements to it. Sorry if this looks junky, I don't know how to edit/format posts to look properly.  Open the Marlin firmware up in the Arduino IDE and locate the tab named : Marlin_main.cpp

author: pmarxx

title: Deck Rail Planter support with drain

description.text:
This is a support to hold terra cotta planters up off of my wooden deck rails. It has a channel inside that allows drainage from the drain holes to flow out and away from the wood.

My deck rail is a standard 1 x 6 pressure treated board. Opening on part that goes onto rail is 142mm.

I have included a 2mm thick test version if the STL file. This can be printed as a template to test the fit on your own rail before committing to printing the entire thing. If you find that it is too wide, feel free to message me. I can easily modify it to bring the inner wall in 2-3mm on each side to give it a smaller opening.

NOTE: I learned that not all terra cotta planters are created equal. I designed this for one planter and then printed two more for the second planter (which was bought at a different time). It was too narrow. I modified the file to open it up. The first one created is 133mm and the second is 141mm. This is the depth of the planter from front to back. Both STLs are posted along with a 2mm thick test STL.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I used 4 solid layers for the top and bottom shells and 3 for the sides.
Supports are needed for the channel. I set the supports to have .4mm of horizontal offset from the part to make it easy to pull out of the channel (and it is).

description.text:
Show your dedication to the Impire by covering your fans with my eye-balled version of the cog!

My basic story is that I had a different 40mm fan guard that worked fine until I moved my fan location and found out my fan's fins stick out just above the top edge of the frame. Meaning I needed a new fan grill that slightly raised off the frame so it wouldn't rub the fan fins. In doing so I thought I'd make a couple other variations as well.

These are being used on my Printrbot Simple Metal with an E3D v6 conversion.

These grills are fairly thin on purpose. Please do be careful knowing they are fragile.

Design

I used Onshape to 3D model my eyeballed cog shape inside good fan grill dimensions.
In honor of the Disney Trip we went on this year for band, I embossified a picture that I had taken while in the Magic Kingdom and made a stamp. I then used Tinkercad to put it together.

author: sebastiann

description.text: UPDATE: See my upgraded "FANCY VERSION" here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:170250 The Nexus 4 wireless charger orb (http://www.amazon.com/Google-Nexus-4-Wireless-Charger/dp/B00BGSPIP2) would be awesome if it would hold the phone reliably to prevent it from slipping off. But most reviews gave it 1 star for being useless because the phone slips off and it doesn't charge anymore. I got it anyway and experienced the same problem. So I made this stand for it which holds the wireless charger upright, and has a little lip to keep it from moving around (but doesn't obstruct the device). It was designed so you can drop the phone on it both upright and sideways, and it will not only charge, but you can use it while it's charging! You might want to use some double-sided tape to hold the orb in place in the frame, though I'm pretty sure it would work without. This tape is freakin' awesome: http://www.amazon.com/Scotch-Heavy-Duty-Mounting-Clear/dp/B00004Z4BU. It is spongy and the adhesive is very strong. I use it for everything around the house, and was especially perfect for keeping this thing together. You might consider using it hold the stand down to the desk, too. Additionally, you can drill through the "tongue" on the bottom to attach it to the edge of a desk (see desk pictures). I didn't put screw holes in it, but it's pretty easy to drill through so you don't really need it. When attached like this, it's solid as a rock and still works in both portrait and landscape mode!

Designed in Blender.  
Tolerances are pretty important here, and you might have to scale the whole thing up or down by 1-2% to fit the charger well.  I recommend printing the top/frame first, and make sure it fits.  If it's too small, scale it up by 1%.  Then make sure you also scale the base by 1% too!

description.text:
This is OneArm Module which would be plugged into modified version of eNable The Future Team
UnLimbited Arm and Phoenix Hand. The outcome would enhance the devices into simple bionic version inlow cost.

This project is a collaboration works between Hong Kong Maker Club and One Degree Production ServicesLtd for the DBS Social Innovators 2016. We have used 3D printed prosthetic devices (such as Team UnLimbited Arm and Phoenix Hand) to help Hong Kong children who born missing fingers or born an armwith an elbow but no wrist. All the current devices require the children to use their wrist or elbow to body drive for actions. Unfortunately, the children are born with very short palm or short residual forearm, theyare hard to drive these devices. Besides, we also received comments from their parents for requesting of electronic version of the 3D printed prosthetic devices. Finally, we designed the OneArm Module to fit their needs. We would like to start this project as an open source project and contribute to eNable The Future Community. Other people can contribute their works, finally, would enhance the devices to fit more children.

OneArm Module Parts:

  • Arduino Micro Pro (5V 16Mhz)
  • Customized Motor Shield with TB6612FNG and input pins 2 sensors. 2 built-in variable resistors to adjust the sensitivity.
  • Customized SG-105 IR reflective sensor board
  • Motor with Gear Box
  • 7.2V LiPo Battery

3D printed Parts (Designed by Mr. Dick Cho [http://www.thingiverse.com/below_cho/about] ):

  • Mount boxes for controller, geared motor and battery
  • Customized Tensor box
  • Modified version of UnLimbited Arm
  • Modified version of Phoenix Hand Palm

Videos:
https://youtu.be/6_4WmTkMZP0
https://youtu.be/TryJMhWGu94
https://youtu.be/WX2V2gbQN6I

Assembly Guide:
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bzl3RqbE2zm3ZDJ6X3ZIRDlPa2M

Design files, PCB and Programme Code: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1674507

Facebook Group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/485331144967242/

This is an open source project and all the materials are opened to public to access. We hope other contributors would help to improve the designs and functions. You are welcome to download the STL files and make your own PCB. If you want to buy the kits for testing, please visit our web store http://www.onedpro.com/#!shop/du9pj . All the parts are available.

  1. Phoenix Hand with OneArm Module

Path: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bzl3RqbE2zm3dTVNZWpyQThOU2M

  1. Team UnLimbited Arm with OneArm Module

Path: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0Bzl3RqbE2zm3WS1OblNXZjJCb3M

title: 3 in 1 buse cooling for BQ Hephestos 1

description.text:
Cette pièce augmente le volume d'air du refroidisseur, ventile le PTFE pour une durée de vie plus grande et éclaire la zone d'impression.
Pratique, l'ensemble se démonte d'une main grace à un connecteur inclus dans les pièces.
Ces pièces sont dessinées pour êtres imprimés avec une buse de 0.4mm, mais avec une buse de 0.2mm le résultat sera encore plus propre
Vous pouvez trouver le montage et le kit ici http://premium-forum.fr/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=1141
Mesures de températures http://premium-forum.fr/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=1064&p=8828#p7365
Consultez aussi le remix qui est une évolution de ces pièces.

This part increasing air flow, cooled PTFE and illuminate the print area.
Practice, it withdraws from a hand
See Premium remix for magnet version

Printer:

Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100µ

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports are included
Print with good PLA (Innofil)

Leds

L'éclairage est constitué de 2 x 3 led 3mm blanches montées en série avec une résistance de 150 ohms par groupe de 3 led. (monter les led sur une plaquette d'essai en coupant les pates à raz du circuit avant de les souder)
Chaque groupe de 3 est branché sur le 12V du ventilateur de l'extrudeur.
Il n'y a donc aucun câble à passer mais juste à souder les deux fils avant le connecteur du ventilateur (ca permet de démonter le ventilateur sans dessouder les fils).
Respectez les polaritées des led (longue broche relié à la courte de la suivante et ainsi de suite).
Le câble qui va aux groupes de led doit être très fin, env. 0,8mm avec la gaine. Le guidage à l'intérieur des bras est facilité en utilisant un tire fil en plastique semi-rigide.
Le kit de pièces est ici https://boutique.premium-computer.fr/shop/imprimantes/kit-tobera-led/

Suppression de la vis qui sera remplée par un aimant

Dans quelques jour je mettrais en ligne un nouveau dessin qui permettra de s'affranchir de la vis grâce à un aimant adapté qui sera inclus dans le kit led.
J'ai testé, ca tient parfaitement en place, plus rapide et encore plus pratique.

title: Meade telescope to Sony FE/E-mount Adapter

description.text: Simple telescope eyepiece tube to FE/E-mount adapter that allows a Sony camera to use a Meade telescope as a lens.

Print this upside-down (flip the STL object so the thin tube portion is printed first) and have your slicer add a little brim to keep it secure during printing. I used PLA at 0.25mm with 2 shells and 40% fill.  
The "MEADE FE/E" label text doesn't print very readably... oh well. Tough to print small text on the underside of a 45-degree slope. Even after filling the letter indentations with white paint it's not pretty, but the text does label it and tells you which side is up.  
The adapter works nicely. It was not a very clear night, but the moon was shot straightforwardly using this adapter to put my NEX-5 on a Meade 1250mm f/13.8.

comments.text: Just curious, can you print it without support material?
comments.author: WestMD

comments.text: Absolutely. That's why the 45-degree slope to the E-mount part: it prints without support with the E-mount side up, tube down -- in other words, upside down compared to the way the STL file presents it. I often design things in the natural orientation and then rotate them for printing when slicing using cura. Use a little brim to increase the surface area on the tube so it sticks to the bed better while printing.
comments.author: WestMD

title: Ops Core gopro nvg mount for FMA heltmet or mich and sport cameras go pro sj4000

description.text:
Esta pieza a sido diseñada para sujetar tu camara de accion tipo (Go pro, sj4000 etc...) a la montura Ops core de tu casco Fast Jump o mich. La pieza ha sido probada durante 6 meses y tienen garantizada su funcion de uso. Hay dos versiones. Colgadas:

fma_gopro_sjcam_adapter_v2 teletubie_set Esta pieza situa la camara por encima del casco, por eso se llama V2 Teletubie.

fma_gopro_sjcam_adapter_v4_set Esta pieza, que es la que recomiendo da la vuelta la camara dando un perfil mas bajo y acercando mas a la vista real del usuario.

Hay un video disponible mostrando la pieza a modo de review el enlace es: https://youtu.be/K2p181J7eJw

Si os gusta el airsoft. No olvidéis ver mi canal de Youtube donde cuelgo reviews y reparaciones sobre pistolas de airsoft. Este lo encontrareis en la siguiente direccion: https://www.youtube.com/user/fransolomon

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa i3 stell

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

Los dos archivos que incluyo son los set de piezas completos. Aparte necesitas las siguientes piezas que no son imprimibles:
Dos tornillos de M3 x 8 tipo allen
Dos tuercas de M3
Tornillo rosca plastico de 3,8 x 15 (opcional y de refuerzo)

Piezas no imprimirles necesarias.

2 x Tornillos de M3 x 6mm tipo allen
2 x Tuercas M3
1 x Tuerca rosca plastico (opcional)
Pegamento loctite

Instrucciones de montaje

Una vez impreso el set de piezas querido:

Insertar las dos tuercas de M3 en sus zocalos correspondientes a la pieza de cierre.

step 1

Step 2: Insertar la pieza de cierre y atornillar los tornillos de M3 x 6 en la zona indicada.

step 2

step 3: Con pegamento loctite o de cianocrilato depositar un poco en la zona marcada. Esperar a que se seque.

step 3 Optional. para reforzar la pieza

step 4. Es te paso es opcional, sirve para hacer mas dura la pieza a los golpes.
Insertar un tornillo de M3 x 15 mm por la zona designada.

step 4. optional Descripcion de piezas incluidas en cada set

1 x Base de montaje Ops Core
1 x Mecanismo de enganche.
1 x Brazo de sujecion de camara invertido (solo version v4)

comments.text: Muy buen trabajo
comments.author: leyenda97

comments.text: en la version 4, como imprimiste la parte de al medio sin soportes?
comments.author: dezmaeth

comments.text: Buenas Dezmaeth la pieza de soporte de la camara v4 no requiere soportes. Muy importante para que quede bien que la imprimas en la posición tal como muestro en la imagen 3 de la ficha de thingiverse. Es decir con las pletinas de sujeción hacia arriba y la base de impresión a la contra. El diseño esta pensado para no usar soportes pero la pieza de sujeción suele quedar mejor la parte donde desliza la pletina que enclavamiento si usas soportes. Un saludo y si te surgen mas dudas no dudes en contactar.

author: lemouchon

title: DotBotS - Support for Arduino UNO and breadboard used to create small robots

description.text:
Support for Arduino UNO and breadboard to make the first experiments with Arduino.
The support can be used as a small robot.
DotBot S has been used at school to teach coding to primary school students.
This project is the small version of the project DotBot http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1441937

Since it is an open source platform the robot can be freely modified, copied, and shared across the Internet.
In addition, it is extremely cheap, in fact the cost almost exclusively determined by the cost of servo motors, electronics and sensors.

This work has been created by two professors:

Michele Maffucci - IIS Galilei Ferrari - Torino - Italy
Ludovico Russo - Researcher - Politecnico di Torino - Italy

Hardware:

1 x chassis
1 x battery holder
2 x Ball Caster
1 x breadboard holder
14 x nut M3

author: Dotbot-io

description.text:
This little demo bot connects an Arduino 101 board, a motor shield, an Android app, and 3D printing all into a single fun learning package. The Arduino 101 board has built in BluetoothLE which receives commands from your Android phone using an app developed with MIT's easy-to-use App Inventor. I've included in the thing files the Arduino source code (.ino file), the Android App Inventor project file (.aia file) and a pre-built Android app (.apk file). You'll also need to download and print the board and battery enclosure found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1673549

Also see: https://github.com/Seamonsters-2605/Ardroid for a more complete example of the Arduino and Android code.

This is a charger stand for my Nexus 7 using a Nokia wireless charging pad.

I got tired of constantly mis-aligning the tablet with the charger. If it was off-center at all the charger efficiency would go down or would not charge the tablet at all. My first solution was just a platform with a conforming hole in it, but was not very aesthetically pleasing, so I came up with this one.

Interlocks between the top and bottom pieces are nubs along the sides. I could not fit the entire stand on my printer bed. Note the notch in the top piece; it allows the power cord plug space, along with a channel for the power cord under the plaque at the top.

print_settings.Notes:: The model came out of Autodesk on its side, but I recommend printing it upside down, with the base and small hole at the top, so it kinda makes a "top hat" shape.

description.text: I modeled this KitchenAid pusher in Autodesk fusion since the one that came with my KitchenAid food processor was broken. It seems that this acrylic that they use for the pusher is very brittle. I modeled this for any thermoplastic, but I printed it in woodfill . I also considered using PET since that is more "food safe approved". However I don't think PLA is very toxic either given when I know about it's chemistry. This should work for model KFP0722ER, but I believe it work for other models as well.

title: Conscript (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE- This entry now includes an OpenTactics stat card. You can find this and other OpenTactics characters in this expanding collection.

I recently designed a new series of Pocket-Tactics models meant to print standing without supports (though support may help a bit, depending on your printer calibration) and we abandoned this style in favor of a new one for the next edition (coming soon!). The models go well with our regular 18mm range, so I decided I should go ahead and post them for you rather than just let them go to waste. As with the other 18mm stuff, if you want a 28mm version, increase the size by 166.6% (that'll get you to a 25mm base and the correct model proportions).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text: This is the STL file for a front plate for a 4.3" LCD display. I've been working on a proof of concept touchscreen replacement for the Gen4 Interface Board. You can see the video here http://dl.dropbox.com/u/6717742/Gen4Touchscreen.m4v The video shows Jetty's firmware http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15380 , but will work with the original or future firmware written to support the original Gen4 Interface Board.

comments.text: Very cool.  Is this a 4D display?  What Microcontroller are you using?  I have a 4.3" 4D touch display that needs a home.
comments.author: WardElder

comments.text: I used a Propeller chip from Parallax Inc. Having 8 cores helps with this kind of project as you can handle all of the user input responsively, draw the display, and still be able to handle the data coming in from the makerbot 4-bit data bus.
comments.author: WardElder

comments.text: Looks like an awesome thing!
comments.author: aubenc

comments.text: As I said, this really was just a proof of concept. It requires a fair amount of solder work and various parts, including a microcontroller, LCD touchscreen and breakout board, and a interface board that will require a chunk of soldering. If several people are interested in building their own I can try to put some instructions together.
comments.author: aubenc

comments.text: My mouth just about dropped open when I saw this video. I know it would probably be a lot of work and I have a prusa mendel instead of a makerbot so I don't know how it would translate, but it would be amazing to see how you did this. Really great work!
comments.author: Kerry

comments.text: I don't understand half of what you just said but I approve.  The video says it all.  It works.  Awesome.  :)

title: Roof Lights and Satellite Antenna Combination for the Traxxas Slash or Other

description.text:
This accessory that i have designed for the proline desert rat body short course truck body now discontinued this will work on the roofs of most RC short course truck bodies
that have almost flat roofs in most cases. But I warn you that this design will
not fit on all short course truck bodies roofs due to their design differences on the
roofs so be aware of that. You may have to do some sending and modification with the roof lights and satellite antenna combination in order to get it to fit onto the roof of your
RC vehicle roof so be aware of that. If you decide to have this part 3-D printed out,
you will need to get 2 3 x 12 mm screws and you will also need to get double-sided tape
if I were you I will get some good double-sided tape that will mold onto the roof of your
short course truck RC body. As you see in some of the photos that I give your and idea in
the order on how this part is to be assembled and where the two 3 x 12 mm screws should go and also and were to put the double-sided tape and how to install it onto the roof of the RC vehicles truck body

Here's an attempt at Sansa's necklace bead from the the Darth Sansa scene in Game of Thrones season 4. It measures approximately 70mm across and 10mm tall, and is a little flatter on the bottom than the top so printing will be easier.

This would make an excellent tutorial object in 123D Design - create a cylinder with 35mm radius & 10mm height, create a cylinder with a 25mm radius, move the small one to overlap the big one, subtract the small one from the large, create a 10x10x50mm rectangle, merge, then fillet the edges.

title: CNC Ninja Domo*pes CNC Snap UPGRADE PARTS w/ TOOL HOLDER

description.text:
I recently built the Ninja CNC kit from CNCSNAP.com. They include some pretty good harware but I wanted my machine to be able to cut heavier material. So i began making upgrades to the machine. I replaced the laser cut motor mounts with HEAVY DUTY 3D printed ones that are probably a little "over" built. But stronger is better right? I also designed a very robust tool holder that fits the motor they supply with the kit. I love this tool holder, it works great. Note: you will need to drill a hole in the end of the clamp to bolt it together. I recommend a small diameter machine screw. Next I stiffened up the guide rods with a set of support claps on each rod. I made them slightly under sized so you will need to run a 1/4" drill through them. My "Y" axis coupler broke so I replaced it with thing 7059. I can't find the corner bracket file I used to stiffen up the frame but I'll post it when I do. I also bolted together my "Z" carriage because it wanted to split with putting the tool holder one it.
If you have any questions or want me to make other upgrade/ design changes just let me know.
Thanks and I hope you put these files to good use. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GYD6TE_If6U
Print them out and swap the existing hardware for the new ones. Or add structural components as per the photos.

comments.text: Hello,what kind of motor is this? What kind of drill chuck is this?
comments.author: JuanS36

comments.text: Hi. I scrapped this machine some time ago. I do recall that they provided this motor from a hand held engraving tool. It had low quality bearings which made the cutting tools orbit wildly. I recomend using a small Dremel tool instead.
comments.author: JuanS36

comments.text: So, would you buy your ninja over again if you were able to re-do or go with something else like a Zen Toolworks kit?  Your printed parts do look beefy.
comments.author: RyGuy

comments.text: Well they both have their advantages an disadvantages. The obvious point is price. The ninja cnc is less expensive w/ electronics than the base zen kit w/out electronics. The ninja is also USB while lots of the available controllers are not. The ninja uses open source electronics with I also love. Plus I have a 3d printer to make all the upgrades I want. So yea I would do it over again. It fits my current needs.

remixed_from.title: Silicone cover for E3D V6 hotend

title: E3D (and clones) V5 heater block Silicone Mould.

description.text:
A file to print a mould to make a silicone hot end cover for an E3D (and clones) V5 heater block.

Print both parts, de-bur the inside of the container and the outside of the insert. Coat in vaseline. Then half fill the container with high temperature silicone rubber. Insert the insert and press gently down until it is in place. Allow to set. Once set remove the insert gently but firmly, you might have to cut the container away, so this is easier with ABS than PLA.

The best silicone is high temperature two-part mix (addition cured silicone) available for mould making/special effects etc... You can use high temperature instant gasket material which sets by contact with air, this however will take many days to set, there is a little porosity in a 3d printed model and this allows it to set eventually.

Make sure when reassembling your hot end no little flaps of silicone get into the threads of the heatbreak/nozzle etc..

comments.text: Hi 3dlyx, we found the opposite to be true.  The waiting nozzle oozes.  So you end up with more mixing of plastic throughout the print.  Our best success has been to print one color on another.
comments.author: CentaurDesign

comments.text: Ya, I had the same experience with mixing the filaments due to oozing. But since I switched to slic3r I use the 'ooze prevention' and 'wipe' features. When switching the extruder while printing, it retracts the filament a few mm and cools the 'passive' extruder down by 5°C. Oozing seems to be not a problem anymore for me. When printing dual colors on top of each other I had problems with the layer binding of the two colors. In a case like this pendant this shouldnt be a problem, but I made some Key-Hangers that just fell off.
comments.author: CentaurDesign

comments.text: We haven't tried using slic3r with our makerbot yet, so that is good to know.  Thanks for the info!
comments.author: 3dlyx

comments.text: Hi, when dealing with multimaterials I found it a good practice to not just print one color on another but to make both colors be present on each (or most) of the layers. This prevents the 'waiting' nozzle getting hot or clogged. All there is to do ist just to bool the two objects, so that the base color has an 'engraving' where the second color fits in.

print_settings.Notes:: print at the highest resolution you can - as the lines are designed to be .1mm thick, as the calibration is for very fine focus

description.text:
I have put this together to be used to calibrate the microfocus on DSLR cameras - still to print and test, this should be treated as an untested prototype

Cura is showing that this will take 52 hours and 38 meters of filament to print at .05mm layer height

or 26 hours at .1mm layer height

if you scale it to 50%, then it will take 11 hours and 7m of filament at .05mm layer height - it should still work - provided the lines are clear enough for the camera to focus on

I would recommend printing in white and painting the lines in black (or vice versa), to allow for easier focusing.

I printed this myself at both 50% and 100% scale - sadly my printer does no have the accuracy to print the calibration lines. as a result, I have edited and provided a v2 file where the calibration lines are 1mm thick, this should print a bit better on models with lower accuracy - I am testing now at 50% scale, results will be posted later.

description.text:
UPDATE- This entry now includes an OpenTactics stat card. You can find this and other OpenTactics characters in this expanding collection.

I recently designed a new series of Pocket-Tactics models meant to print standing without supports (though support may help a bit, depending on your printer calibration) and we abandoned this style in favor of a new one for the next edition (coming soon!). The models go well with our regular 18mm range, so I decided I should go ahead and post them for you rather than just let them go to waste. As with the other 18mm stuff, if you want a 28mm version, increase the size by 166.6% (that'll get you to a 25mm base and the correct model proportions).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!
